column2: U.S. states probe massive data breach at health insurer AnthemUPDATE 4-U.S. states probe massive data breach at health insurer AnthemHealth insurer Anthem hit by massive cybersecurity breachU.S. states probe massive data breach at health insurer AnthemAnthem warns consumers of email scamUPDATE 2-Anthem warns U.S. customers of email scam after data breach Feb 6 Health insurer Anthem Inc on Friday warned U.S. customers about an email scam targeting former and current members whose personal information was suspected to have been breached in a massive cyber attack. column3: a deal that would form an industry giant better equipped to withstand rising aluminum costs.

column2: U.S. Navy plans more intensive review of H-53 helicopters WASHINGTON
column3: Feb 5 The U.S. Navy on Thursday said it was launching a more intensive effort to ensure that any wiring or fuel line problems with its CH-53E and MH-53E heavy-lift helicopters are corrected as quickly and effectively as possible.

column2: DuPont rebuffs Peltz demand for board seat as proxy battle nears DuPont said on Thursday it rebuffed an attempt by activist shareholder Trian Fund Management to put its chief executive
column5: instead naming two of its own nominees as directors.

column2: EBay restates quarterly profit to reflect lower income tax Feb 6 EBay Inc raised its reported fourth-quarter net income by $87 million to reflect a reduction in income tax expense.

column3: shares slide Feb 5 Expedia Inc's fourth-quarter profit fell more than 30 percent from a year ago
column5: partly due to the stronger dollar and intense competition in China.

column4: Feb 5 Verizon Communications  said it would sell wireline assets to Frontier Communications for $10.54 billion in cash and sell and lease cell phone towers for around $5 billion to American Tower in a deal that will help it pay off recent wireless spectrum purchases.

column2: U.S. defense suppliers Harris and Exelis to combine Harris Corp said on Friday it would buy Exelis Inc in a deal valued at about $4.75 billion
column3: potentially kicking off a long-expected consolidation of mid-tier suppliers to the U.S. military after years of declining defense budgets.

column2: Medtronic to pay $2.8 mln to resolve false claims -U.S. Justice Dept WASHINGTON
column3: Feb 6 Medical device manufacturer Medtronic has agreed to pay $2.8 million to resolve allegations that it caused certain physicians to submit false claims to federal healthcare programs for a medical procedure known as "SubQ stimulation
column4:

PRU,Judge tosses much of Prudential mortgage lawsuit against BofAJudge tosses much of Prudential mortgage lawsuit against BofA A federal judge has thrown out much of Prudential Financial Inc's lawsuit accusing Bank of America Corp of defrauding it before the financial crisis into buying more than $1.9 billion of residential mortgage-backed securities that later soured. RTN,Raytheon GPS ground program passes review, delays still possible WASHINGTON, Feb 6 A $1.6 billion ground control system being developed by Raytheon Co for Global Positioning System (GPS)satellites passed a Pentagon review, but will be monitored to ensure it stays on track, a senior Air Force official said on Friday. 
SYMC,U.S. court orders Symantec to pay $17 mln for patent infringementUPDATE 1-U.S. court orders Symantec to pay $17 mln for patent infringementU.S. court orders Symantec to pay $17 mln for patent infringement Symantec Corp, maker of the popular Norton antivirus software, was ordered to pay $17 million in damages on Friday after a federal jury in Delaware found it had violated two patents owned by Intellectual Ventures, a major patent licensing company. TXT,Northrop surprises with new design for U.S. Air Force trainer WASHINGTON, Feb 6 Northrop Grumman Corp  said on Friday it is designing and already building a new aircraft for the upcoming U.S. Air Force T-X competition to build 350 new training planes, an $11 billion program that analysts say could double in value in coming years. 
FOXA,Top Fox investors seek to convert voting shares, Murdoch may benefit: sources NEW YORK Several top investors in Twenty-First Century Fox Inc are pressing for the right to swap their voting shares for ordinary shares, which are trading at an unusual premium, even though the move could hand even more control of the company to Rupert Murdoch, according to people familiar with the matter. 
FOX,Top Fox investors seek to convert voting shares, Murdoch may benefit: sources NEW YORK Several top investors in Twenty-First Century Fox Inc are pressing for the right to swap their voting shares for ordinary shares, which are trading at an unusual premium, even though the move could hand even more control of the company to Rupert Murdoch, according to people familiar with the matter. 
UTX,Pratt says growth in F-35 production will help cut costsPratt says growth in F-35 production will help cut costs WASHINGTON The Pentagon's plans to fund 50 percent more F-35 fighter jets in fiscal 2016 will help drive down the price of the new plane and its engine, a top official with enginemaker Pratt & Whitney, a unit of United Technologies Corp, said Thursday.  Pratt says growth in F-35 production will help cut costs WASHINGTON The Pentagon's plans to fund 50 percent more F-35 fighter jets in fiscal 2016 will help drive down the price of the new plane and its engine, a top official with enginemaker Pratt & Whitney, a unit of United Technologies Corp, said Thursday. VZ,UPDATE 4-Verizon to sell wireline operations, towers worth $15.6 bln SAN FRANCISCO, Feb 5 Verizon Communications  said it would sell wireline assets to Frontier Communications for $10.54 billion in cash and sell and lease cell phone towers for around $5 billion to American Tower in a deal that will help it pay off recent wireless spectrum purchases. 
YHOO,Feds can't indefinitely gag Yahoo about subpoena, judge rulesFeds can't indefinitely gag Yahoo about subpoena, judge rules SAN FRANCISCO Law enforcement cannot indefinitely forbid Yahoo Inc from revealing a grand jury subpoena that seeks subscriber account information, a U.S. judge ruled, because doing so would violate the company's free speech rights.
